cards.name: Kākāpō
cards.flavorText: The world's heaviest parrot, it can't fly. Only 250 remain, breeding once every 2-4 years.

cards.name: Carrier Pigeon
cards.flavorText: Homing pigeons navigate using Earth's magnetic field, infrasound, and visual landmarks.

cards.name: Common Swift
cards.flavorText: Swifts can stay airborne for 10 months straight, sleeping, eating, and mating in flight.

cards.name: Doctor Bird
cards.flavorText: Jamaica's national bird, the red-billed streamertail beats its wings 80 times per second.

cards.name: Doves
cards.flavorText: Doves produce crop milk -- a nutrient-rich secretion to feed their chicks, like mammalian lactation.

cards.name: Eurasian Magpie
cards.flavorText: One of the few non-mammals to pass the mirror test, recognizing its own reflection.

cards.name: Golden-Headed Manakin
cards.flavorText: Males perform a moonwalk-like slide on branches to impress females, snapping wing feathers audibly.

cards.name: Golden Song Sparrows
cards.flavorText: Song sparrows learn regional dialects; neighboring populations sing noticeably different tunes.

cards.name: Mexican Violetear
cards.flavorText: This hummingbird's iridescent violet ear patches shift color depending on the angle of light.

params.title: Choose a carrion to copy abilities from

cards.name: Mockingbird
cards.flavorText: A single mockingbird can learn over 200 songs, mimicking other birds, frogs, and car alarms.

params.title: Choose a creature to copy stats from

cards.name: Moluccan Cockatoo
cards.flavorText: Cockatoos are among the few animals that craft tools, trimming sticks to extract grubs from bark.

params.title: Choose a creature to copy abilities from

cards.name: Oriental Magpies
cards.flavorText: Oriental magpies mate for life and hold "funerals," gathering around their dead in silence.

cards.name: Quetzal
cards.flavorText: Quetzals swallow avocados whole, then regurgitate the pits -- making them key seed dispersers.

cards.name: Raven
cards.flavorText: Ravens cache food in dozens of locations and remember each one for months.

params.title: Choose a carrion to copy stats from

cards.name: Robin
cards.flavorText: Robins can see Earth's magnetic field through quantum effects in proteins in their eyes.

cards.name: Seagull
cards.flavorText: Gulls drink both fresh and salt water, filtering out salt through glands above their eyes.

cards.name: White Bellbird
cards.flavorText: At 125 decibels, its mating call is as loud as a rock concert -- the loudest bird on record.

cards.name: Hoatzin
cards.flavorText: The only bird that digests leaves by fermentation, like a cow. Nicknamed the "stinkbird."

cards.name: Golden Goose
cards.flavorText: Domestic geese were among the first animals domesticated, over 3,000 years ago in ancient Egypt.

cards.name: Indian Peacock
cards.flavorText: A peacock's tail has microscopic crystal structures that create color through light interference, not pigment.

cards.name: Jersey Giant
cards.flavorText: The largest chicken breed, Jersey Giants can weigh over 13 lbs and were bred to replace turkeys.

cards.name: Pileated Woodpecker
cards.flavorText: It strikes wood at 20 times per second. A spongy skull bone absorbs the shock of each impact.

cards.name: Black Swan
cards.flavorText: Native only to Australia, black swans were once thought impossible by Europeans -- inspiring a philosophy term.

cards.name: Eastern Wild Turkey
cards.flavorText: Wild turkeys can fly at 55 mph in bursts and roost in trees, unlike their domestic relatives.

cards.name: Black-and-white Hawk-eagle
cards.flavorText: This eagle hunts toucans, macaws, and monkeys in the treetops of Central and South American rainforests.

cards.name: Firehawk
cards.flavorText: Black kites and brown falcons carry burning sticks to start new fires, flushing prey into the open.

cards.name: Great Gray Owl
cards.flavorText: Its facial disc funnels sound so precisely it can locate and catch voles under two feet of snow.

params.title: Choose a carrion to add to hand

cards.name: Short-toed Snake Eagle
cards.flavorText: Specializing in reptiles, it hovers like a kestrel to spot snakes, then crushes their heads mid-air.

cards.name: Wolf Hawk
cards.flavorText: The Harris's hawk hunts cooperatively in packs of 2-6, the only raptor known to do so regularly.

cards.name: Peregrine Falcon
cards.flavorText: In a hunting stoop, it reaches 240 mph -- the fastest animal on Earth by a wide margin.

cards.name: Red-tailed Hawk
cards.flavorText: Hollywood dubs its raspy scream over bald eagle footage -- the eagle's real call is a weak chirp.

cards.name: Monkey-eating Eagle
cards.flavorText: With a 7-foot wingspan, the Philippine eagle is critically endangered -- fewer than 800 remain in the wild.

cards.name: Gyrfalcon
cards.flavorText: The largest true falcon, gyrfalcons hunt ptarmigan in the Arctic and were worth more than gold to medieval kings.

cards.name: Golden Eagle
cards.flavorText: Golden eagles can spot a rabbit from two miles away. Mongolian hunters still use them to catch wolves.

cards.name: Martial Eagle
cards.flavorText: Africa's largest eagle, it preys on monitor lizards, jackals, and small antelopes up to 35 lbs.

cards.name: Harpy Eagle
cards.flavorText: Its talons exert 530 psi of pressure -- strong enough to crush a howler monkey's skull instantly.

cards.name: Pacific Sea Eagle
cards.flavorText: Steller's sea eagle has the largest wingspan of any eagle at nearly 8 feet and weighs up to 20 lbs.

cards.name: Bird Food
cards.flavorText: Wild birds need high-fat seeds in winter; a chickadee must eat its body weight daily to survive the cold.

cards.name: Birds of a Feather
cards.flavorText: Mixed-species flocks are common: different birds forage together to share predator-detection duties.

cards.name: Shotgun
cards.flavorText: Lead shot was banned for waterfowl hunting in 1991 after poisoning millions of birds who ingested spent pellets.

options.label: Deal 2 damage to rival and creatures
options.description: Deal 2 damage to Rival and Rival's creatures

options.label: Deal 6 damage to target Rival's creature
options.description: Select a Rival's creature for 6 damage

cards.name: Swan Song
cards.flavorText: Mute swans aren't actually mute -- they hiss, grunt, and snort. The "swan song" myth is ancient Greek.

cards.name: Bird's Eye View
cards.flavorText: Raptors see UV light and have 8x the visual acuity of humans, spotting prey from over a mile up.

cards.name: White Feathers
cards.flavorText: Down feathers trap air in a 3D lattice, insulating so well that Arctic eiders survive -40 degrees.

cards.name: White Missile
cards.flavorText: Bird droppings are white because birds excrete uric acid instead of urea -- it saves water.

cards.name: Alleyway Mobbing
cards.flavorText: Small birds mob predators in coordinated attacks, dive-bombing owls and hawks until they flee the area.

cards.name: Fly Off
cards.flavorText: Bar-headed geese migrate over the Himalayas at 29,000 feet, where oxygen is a third of sea level.

cards.name: Icarus
cards.flavorText: Bird bones are hollow but reinforced with internal struts, making them lighter than mammal bones yet just as strong.
